question: At a stop sign, where must you stop if a stop line is painted?
choices: Anywhere before the intersection
Beside the stop sign post
At the painted stop line
Halfway into the intersection to see better
explanation: You must come to a complete stop at the painted stop line. If there’s no stop line, stop at the crosswalk; if none, at the edge of the sidewalk; if none, at the edge of the intersection.

question: Approaching a YIELD sign and cross traffic is present. What must you do?
choices: Proceed without stopping if you signal
Slow down, be prepared to stop, and yield the right-of-way to traffic and pedestrians; stop if needed
Always come to a complete stop for at least three seconds
Speed up to merge before other vehicles
explanation: A YIELD sign means you must slow down, be ready to stop, and give the right-of-way to traffic on the road you’re entering and to pedestrians. Stop if required.

question: What does this sign mean?
choices: Left turns allowed only at night
No left turn permitted at any time
Left turn lane begins ahead
U-turns allowed with caution
explanation: A red circle with a slash always means a prohibition. The arrow pointing left with a slash means no left turns are allowed.

Minimum speed 80 km/h
Maximum legal speed 80 km/h under ideal conditions
Speed must always be 80 km/h regardless of conditions
explanation: A white rectangular sign with black numerals indicates the maximum legal speed in kilometres per hour under ideal driving conditions.

question: This sign appears ahead. What does it warn you about?
choices: Bicycles are prohibited on this road
Expect cyclists; bicycle traffic may be crossing or sharing the road
Shared-use path begins; motor vehicles must stop
Bicycle lane ends; merge right immediately
explanation: A yellow diamond bicycle symbol is a warning sign to watch for cyclists and be prepared to slow down or yield as needed.

question: What does this regulatory sign mean?
choices: Pedestrian crossover ahead
School crossing ahead
No pedestrians are allowed beyond this point
Pedestrians must yield to vehicles
explanation: A pedestrian symbol within a red circle with a slash means pedestrians are prohibited beyond that sign.

question: You see this sign at the entrance to a roadway. What must you do?
choices: Proceed slowly and keep right
Enter only if traffic is light
Do not enter — road is for traffic in the opposite direction
Stop and then proceed if clear
explanation: The red circle with a white horizontal bar means DO NOT ENTER — you are facing opposing traffic (e.g., the wrong end of a one-way).

question: This sign shows two cars side-by-side within a red circle. What does it mean?
choices: Passing is allowed if you signal
No passing — you must not overtake other vehicles here
Use the left lane only
Keep right except to pass
explanation: A red circle is a prohibition. The two-car symbol indicates NO PASSING — do not overtake other vehicles where this sign applies.

question: You see this circular blue sign with white arrows before a roundabout. What should you do?
choices: Enter quickly and signal left
Keep right, travel counter-clockwise and yield to traffic already in the roundabout and to pedestrians
Stop and wait for a green signal
U-turn is mandatory at the next exit
explanation: Approach slowly, keep right of the central island, yield to pedestrians and to vehicles already in the roundabout, and enter when there is a safe gap.

question: A school bus coming toward you has its upper red lights flashing (no median). What must you do?
choices: Proceed at 20 km/h with caution
Stop a safe distance away and remain stopped until the red lights stop flashing and the stop arm retracts
Only slow down if children are visible
Stop only if you are within 20 metres of the bus
explanation: On roads without a median, vehicles in both directions must stop for a school bus with red lights flashing and remain stopped until the lights stop and the stop arm retracts.

question: You see this sign ahead. What does it mean for traffic on your approach?
choices: Detour ahead — reduce speed to 30 km/h
Road closed to all traffic — do not proceed
No stopping on this road
Temporary construction access permitted
explanation: A ROAD CLOSED sign means the roadway is closed to traffic. Do not proceed; follow posted detours or instructions.

question: On a two-way road with no median, a school bus ahead of you stops with its upper red lights flashing. What must you do?
choices: Slow to 10 km/h and pass with caution
Stop at least 20 metres behind and remain stopped until the lights stop flashing and the stop arm retracts
Pass if no children are visible on the road
Stop only if you are approaching from the opposite direction
explanation: When a school bus activates its red flashing lights (and/or stop arm), you must stop. If you are behind the bus, stop at least 20 metres away and remain stopped until the red lights stop flashing and the stop arm retracts. On roads with a median, only vehicles behind the bus must stop.

question: At a four-way stop, two vehicles stop at exactly the same time. Who goes first?
choices: The larger vehicle goes first
The vehicle on the left goes first
The vehicle on the right goes first
Whoever flashes headlights first
explanation: If two vehicles stop at the same time at an all-way stop, the vehicle on the left must yield to the vehicle on the right.

question: When is it legal to make a right turn on a red light in Ontario?
choices: Anytime you signal
Only when a police officer waves you through
After a complete stop and only if there is no sign prohibiting it, and you yield to pedestrians and traffic
Only between sunrise and sunset
explanation: You may turn right on red after coming to a full stop, provided there is no sign prohibiting it and you yield to pedestrians and other road users.

question: When must you turn on your headlights in Ontario?
choices: Only after dark
From sunset exactly to sunrise only
Half an hour before sunset to half an hour after sunrise, and whenever visibility is under about 150 m (e.g., fog, rain, snow)
Only on highways
explanation: Headlights are required from one-half hour before sunset to one-half hour after sunrise, and any time poor light conditions prevent you from clearly seeing people or vehicles less than 150 metres away.

question: A school crossing guard steps into the road holding a red-and-white stop sign. What must you do?
choices: Slow down and pass carefully if no children are on the crosswalk
Stop, then proceed if the guard waves only children across
Stop before the crossing and remain stopped until everyone, including the guard, has cleared the entire roadway and it is safe to go
Honk to alert others and proceed
explanation: You must stop before reaching the crossing and remain stopped until all people—including the school crossing guard—have cleared the entire roadway and it is safe to proceed.

question: What is the minimum safe following distance under good conditions for most passenger vehicles?
choices: One second behind the vehicle ahead
Two seconds behind the vehicle ahead
Three car lengths at any speed
Five seconds only on highways
explanation: Use at least the two-second rule to maintain a safe following distance under good conditions. Increase the gap in poor weather or when visibility is low.

question: Approaching a roundabout, what must you do before entering?
choices: Enter quickly and claim your lane
Stop in the entry lane even if no one is coming
Yield to traffic already in the roundabout and to pedestrians, and enter when there is a safe gap
Signal left and enter immediately
explanation: Slow down and yield to circulating traffic and pedestrians. Enter only when there is a safe gap; then signal right when exiting.

question: On a road divided by a median, a school bus on the opposite side stops with red lights flashing. What must you do?
choices: Stop immediately
Proceed with caution; only vehicles behind the bus must stop
Honk and pass
Stop for 3 seconds, then proceed
explanation: On roads with a median, only vehicles behind the bus must stop for its flashing red lights. Opposing traffic may proceed with caution.

question: At a pedestrian crossover (PXO) with flashing beacons, when can you proceed?
choices: As soon as the pedestrian steps onto the curb on your half of the road
After slowing and sounding the horn
Only after pedestrians have completely crossed and fully left the roadway, and it’s safe
Anytime if you are turning right
explanation: You must stop for pedestrians at PXOs and remain stopped until they have completely crossed and are fully off the roadway. Proceed only when it’s safe.
